text: Today I'm presenting a technical artist
guide to profiling in Unreal Engine.
So in this talk I'll present an
accessible workflow for technical
artists and other technically minded
people to efficiently profile worst
performing areas of the game with the
goal of quickly determining the most
effective optimizations to recommend to
content teams. This is not intended to
be a comprehensive overview of all
available performance tools in Unreal
Engine or an expert level talk and
low-level optimization techniques. And
some context is that um I've worked with
a lot of technical artists but also uh
environment artists who are technical uh
QA even producers um who want to have a
better understanding of how to optimize
and how to find good optimizations but
they don't know where to put an effort.
They don't know what tool to use for the
job. They don't know know what all the
bars and colors mean if you open up a
profile in insights, for example. Um,
and they also don't have a good idea
when to stop and pass the investigation
off to a subject matter expert when the
time is right.
So, first of all, we'll figure out where
we want to focus,
where to start. There are a couple
different approaches and we're going to
start with some that aren't technically
profiling, but they are important for
maintaining optimized content.
First of all, we'll want to proactively
check all our art assets as they go into
the editor with Unreal Engine's data
validation plugin. Some examples of this
are simple and complex collision,
landscape grass distance calling,
material count and layer count, mesh
density and max poly count, and also map
checks. On the implementation side, this
is a little bit technical. So if you're
a technical artist, you'll want to work
with engineering on this. And once
they've established a framework, Techart
can definitely help write individual
checks. I also recommend doing this in
C++ for efficiency, especially if you
have a lot of content. Um, but also to
make sure that you're keeping iteration
times down for your content creators.
On the content creator side, it's really
easy and there are a couple different
options for using validation. So, first
of all, you can manually run it through
the content browser. Um, but we've also
added a customization um, a proof force
trigger um, that's used to require
validation on submission via view
changes. Um, and then this will also
show up in the change list description
so you can easily verify um, that all
content is being validated. We're also
running um, validation nightly via the
build machine. Um, and then we'll get a
long list of any uh, validation errors
that have popped up and we can
communicate that easily to our content
creators via Slack. Um, or use whatever
communication channels uh, you prefer
using.
Secondly, um, we can keep an eye on all
assets currently used in the game. And
there are a couple really good tools for
doing this. Um the first one is tools
audit asset asset asset audit um which
you can see on the right hand side. Um
and this is really helpful for gathering
data on assets. Um usually we are
looking at static meshes and it's a
little tricky to actually get that
information if you're not familiar with
this tool. Um, once you have the asset
audit open, you'll want to go to add
asset class and then type in use static
mesh and then you'll see static mesh pop
up. You can select that and then on the
left hand side you can filter down to
just static meshes which will give you
all this beautiful data. Um, there's a
lot of data in here. Um, and I'll get to
that in a sec how we want to process
that. The other tool I want to mention
really quick um is statistics. And
statistics is used to gather data on
objects uh while you're running PI. So
here's an example of that. Um and one
thing that's like really helpful in here
is instance count. So we can take the
other data that was uh from asset audit
including polyc count, material count,
dimensions, is nanite enabled, combine
that with instances used in game um and
then we can start um processing that
data. Both these tools allow you to
export CSV and then techart can write
Python scripts to generate additional
metrics uh based on exported data. They
can filter data just to assets that are
relevant to each of the content teams
that they that they are working with.
Um, and they can also apply conditional
color coding to help content creators
understand where to focus their
optimization efforts. So over here we
have an example of doing that, grabbing
all that data, manipulating it, coming
up with a new metric, um, and then
displaying it in a way that's easily
digestible for content creators so that
they know exactly where to focus their
efforts.
Then lastly, in order to use the times
the team's time most effectively, we
want to make sure that we're focusing
our profiling and optimization efforts
on the content that will give us the
biggest bang for the buck. And
ultimately, our goal here is to make
sure that the game is running at a
reasonable frame rate. It's lovely if
all of our content is well organized,
but at the end of the day, what we
really care about is the game itself.
So,
um, another call out is, um, there are a
lot of really helpful visual debugging
tools and I feel that artists,
especially,
um, being visual people, they tend to
gravitate toward those debug modes. Um,
but they don't always provide you
information about bottlenecks, for
example. So you can spend all day
optimizing for a particular debug mode,
but that might not even be the
bottleneck and then you won't actually
see any big change in frame rate. So um
in order to help focus efforts, um the
first thing that we want to look at is
something like a performance map like
the one over here um that we've
developed internally. Um this was
created by our engineering team. Um and
every um so often our build machine
automatically captures data based on
user added POI markers. Um if you see
the little red squares on the right hand
side, those are our POI markers. Um
there are some that have already been
placed but any user can add additional
POI markers for any location that they
would like to have more data for.
Frame data is also captured to help
provide insight into bottlenecks. Um so
if you look down on the lower half of
the screen, you'll see information
including game thread time, render
thread time, GPU time. This is helpful
um both to figure out what the biggest
bottleneck might be in a certain area,
but you can also compare different
captures to see if there's been a
regression, for example. So it's helpful
for tracking data over time.
The seat map is super easy to use. Um,
it's very helpful. Um, and I highly
suggest creating something like this um,
in order to focus your team.
So, next we'll talk about reproducible
performance testing.
We'll want to pinpoint a location for
performance testing. Um, but we also
want to ensure that we are profiling in
a reproducible way. This is especially
important when you're testing
optimizations in addition to profiling.
So, how do we set up for our
investigations?
First of all, we'll want to launch the
game. You'll want to before you even
launch the game, start Unreal Insights
via the Unreal editor. It's best to do
this beforehand because late connecting
can potentially lead to data issues. So,
just to be safe, we'll do that first.
Next, we'll want to run a development
build of the game. This is going to
provide us the most information during
profiling compared to a test build where
a lot of that information is stripped
out, but in general, we'll run um fast
enough to be generally representative of
um what we're trying to profile. Um we
do want to be mindful though that it's
not going to be exactly representative.
So debug is sometimes going to impact
performance and we should keep that in
mind when we're looking at our profiles.
Um also in UGS um you'll probably want
to confirm that you're synced to a
similar change list is the build to
ensure that symbols match just in case
that's necessary later. Once the game's
running, use this uh trace.s stop
command um to avoid generating a large
trace file. Sometimes it'll take several
minutes, 10 minutes, 20 minutes to find
the spot that you're trying to profile.
Um, we don't want to be generating
gigabytes and gigabytes of data um while
we're just trying to find the spot that
we care about. It'll also make it um
more difficult to find the spot that
you're trying to profile later on.
Then we'll proceed to the area
identified on the heat map in the last
step. Um, and one additional feature of
the tool that we created is that once
you when you select a region, um, it
will create a bucket go command that we
can paste into the, um, command prompt
later, um, to get right to where we want
to go.
So once we've arrived in that location,
we'll want to pinpoint exactly where we
want to test. So that's not just
position, it's also like camera
orientation. So if I'm looking this way,
performance might be fine, but if I
rotate this way, it might get really
bad. So we'll want to keep that in mind,
too. Looking all around to figure out
where that worst spot is that we want to
dig into.
Unreal provides several helpful stat
commands to track performance at a high
level. For example, stat FPS. that will
bring up a small panel on the right hand
side of the screen um that tracks
information on what your frame rate is,
but it's small and it can be difficult
to track it, especially when you're
running around the game, maybe fighting
a boss. Um, and we wanted to create
something that's a little bit easier to
track. Um, which you can see below. Um,
it's part of our in-game performance
monitor that engineering built using
IMU. Lives at the bottom of the screen.
You can actually move it around a little
bit, which is helpful. Um, and you can
see it out of the corner of your eye
when you're playing, which is super
super helpful.
So, I think I have an example here.
So, as you can see, this is totally
fine. But we look at this field of glass
and h that looks a little suspicious. So
I go back to verify and you know what? I
think this is an area over here that I
want to dig into.
So once we've identified the specific
spot we want to profile, we may want to
prepare for an AB test if we plan on
testing optimizations in the future. So
by AB test what I mean is verifying
optimizations by comparing performance
with and without the optimization
ensuring that the optimization is the
only thing or close to it in the frame
that has changed. So couple things that
you'll want to do to prepare for that.
Um run bugget command and save off the
results. That'll get both your position
and orientation.
you'll want to consider controlling all
game state conditions that can cause
differences between captures. So, a lot
of this is going to be movement related.
Um, so if you're using a time of day uh
system, you'll want to control that.
Weather, wind, wetness, that will also
want to be controlled. Any kind of
ambient movement where things are
swaying back and forth a little bit,
that can have an impact. Any am animated
geometry, so movement is the big theme
here. Um, the biggest thing that's
probably going to be moving around your
screen is actually the character. So,
you may also want to consider hiding the
character. Um, we created a custom
command, um, hide player in order to do
this. Uh, this was implemented via the
custom cheat manager. Um, and one thing
to keep in mind if you decide to do this
yourself is make sure that all the
components are hidden too, which will
require a little bit of piping data
around. Um, this is all really helpful
so that like you can literally flip
between screens and see exactly what's
changing. Um, not just from a
performance standpoint, but also from a
visual standpoint because sometimes when
we optimize, there might be slight
visual changes and we want to catch
those and make sure that we're okay with
them. On the flip side, also keep in
mind that if you're doing this, you're
removing things that could potentially
be expensive. So
double check, make sure that when you
disable um these features that they're
not the things that are like adding
significant cost. In that case, you will
want to keep them on and dive into the
profiles with characters, motion, etc.
enabled.
A couple other uh helpful hotkeys and
commands. So there's slow-mo zero, which
pauses the game. really helpful when
you're trying to pinpoint an exact frame
during a cinematic um or similar. Um but
you can also create custom key bindings
by editing uh default input ini um which
you can submit and uh the entire team
will have access to that. Alternatively,
you can edit your local app data user
input ini um and add whatever
[clears throat] commands you would like
to use personally. a few examples um
that we've added. Um if on the numpad
you hit the period key that does slowmo
one. Uh alt period does lomo.1
and control period does slow-mo.01.
So that way we can very carefully step
through and find the exact frame that we
want to profile.
Another helpful tool is console
variables editor for batching commands.
I've already mentioned a few. There are
a few more that I'm going to mention
after this. Um, so that's absolutely
worth investigating um in order to make
your workflow more efficient.
Um, okay. So, next we're going to
determine bottlenecks.
Now that we know where we want to focus,
what tools do we want to use to gather
more information?
So, the first thing we'll want to do is
check stat unit. Um, this will bring up
a panel on the right hand side of the
screen with a couple of different
timings. There's game, frame, draw, GPU
time. And what we'll want to do is
compare these against each other to
figure out where the bottleneck most
likely is.
First thing we want to check is if game
is close to frame, this is likely a game
thread bottleneck. Um, if we see this
happening and the next step in that case
would be to perform an Unreal insights
trace. If draw is close to frame, this
is likely a rendered thread bottleneck.
And because it's also a CPU issue, we'll
still want to perform a Unreal insight
insights trace. However, if GPU time is
close to frame, then it's probably a GPU
bottleneck. And in that case, Unreal
Insights might provide some basic
information, but ultimately we'll
probably end up in profile GPU or a
dedicated GPU debugger in order to
diagnose what the issue is.
Because those numbers uh tend to jump
around frame frame, sometimes it's a
little bit difficult to do that
comparison. Um, so it could help to
visualize it in a graph, and there are a
couple options for that. Um, there's
actually a built-in command in Unreal,
uh, stat unit graph, which will create a
small graph in the corner of your
screen. Um, and it's colorcoded based
on, uh, the panel in the corner. We
created our um, own version of this,
which is part of the performance monitor
that I mentioned earlier. So we can see
that um see those stats over a longer
period of time.
Now that we know what tools we want to
use to profile our issues, we can do a
deep dive.
So what are common patterns we should
look for and when should we consider
passing the investigation to someone
else?
First, we'll start with CPU bottlenecks
in Unreal Insights. So, before we run
the trace, uh we'll want to prepare um
and run the command stats verbose named
events. This will start um oh, and then
we start the trace with the command
trace start. Optionally, you can use
these commands to identify spec specific
frames in your trace. Um there's trace
bookmark and trace screenshot. Um these
are really helpful because you might
have um tens or hundreds or even
thousands of frames in insights. Um if
you use these commands, it'll place a
little marker um in your um graph uh so
that you can find it far more easily. Um
so I definitely recommend using these.
Um you can create custom key bindings
which is really helpful. Um, and then
also in our performance monitor, um,
there's a, uh, frame number stat. So
that way if we're doing a video
recording, we can compare the video
itself, um, against our Unreal Insights
trace. Um, and having context um, is
really helpful. So, for example, if
you're seeing a lot of physics stuff
going on in the trace and then you look
at the frame and there's a big
explosion, you have a better much faster
understanding of what might be
contributing to your performance
problems.
Once you've captured enough data, we
usually run for a couple seconds at a
minimum. You stop the trace with the
command trace stop. And then we'll
switch to Unreal Insights. um select the
trace that we just captured and press
open trace. If for whatever reason you
don't see the trace there, uh just
confirm that the directory containing
the trace is included in the list of
directories to monitor. And once
insights is open, um you'll want to look
at the top panel called the frames panel
to start identifying low frame rate
areas. So you can you can see an example
over here. Um and there are two uh types
of low frame rate areas that we're
looking for. The first type is a hitch
um which you see on the left hand side
and it's that tiny little one-frame
spike. The other area to the right is a
consistently low frame rate area. When
tech artists or others are first getting
started looking at insights captures, I
typically remen recommend to look at the
consistent low FPS areas first. It's
usually a little bit easier to diagnose.
It's also usually more often content
related. Um, so it's um easier to find
actionable optimization recommendations
by looking in those areas.
Next, um, we will select a frame in that
frames panel that we'd like to dig into,
um, which you see
up top here, the little blue box. Um the
selected frame will also be highlighted
in the timings view panel below. Um
which you can see that blue uh large
blue highlighted area there. Um and it's
always a good idea to confirm the
bottleneck. Even though by comparing
those stats earlier we got a good sense
of where it probably is. Never hurts to
look at your trace and identify the
bottleneck. So, if you look at this one
here, we see that there's a large
section of the GPU track where nothing
is happening. Down below in the game
thread, there's a lot of stuff going on.
So this confirms our hypothesis that you
know what this is probably a CPU issue
specifically a game thread issue and the
GPU is stalling because it doesn't have
any work to do because the GP the CPU is
still figuring out what needs to be done
next.
Um
also um you'll or the next step of this
is that you'll want to figure out like
what the specific issue is. So, we know
it's CPU, we know it's game thread. Um,
but like what's specifically about the
game thread is the issue? If we look in
this example, we'll see that there's a
lot of physics stuff going on. Um, and
this looks like
a little suspicious. Probably I'm
guessing like 10 milliseconds of physics
work. Another thing you'll want to make
sure that you have is budgets both for
the CPU but also for the GPU.
And you'll look at this guesstimate that
there's about 10 milliseconds here.
You'll compare that against your CPU
budgets and physics might be 2 or 3
milliseconds and you're like wait a
minute that seems expensive. So that's
the point where you need to either drill
down into this. Um if we skip ahead,
you'll see that there's a lot of stuff

there's a VFX tag attached to it and we
know that's the team that we probably
want to reach out to and let them know
like, hey, we found this thing. Could
you look into optimizing it?
There are other times where there isn't
obvious content that is connected to a
category um that's way over budget. And
in that case, it's usually a good time

a physics programmer who might be able
to dig into this more with all the
context of what is going on. I wouldn't
recommend for tech artists or others to

the entire physics system um when it's a

millisecond deferred shading scene

GPU.

fizz buffer seems a little high and

So we're going to dig a little deeper.
The first thing you'll want to do is run
the following commands to make sure that
there's enough detailed information in
the profile that you're about to do. The
first one is r.tow material draw events
one. That's for everything that's
nonnanite. And then also r.nanite mesh
show mesh draw events one. And that's
for everything that is nanite. You'll
also want to disable async compute and
then run the command profile GPU.
Um just a side note, if you're certain
that the GPU is the issue and it's not

pi. Um if that saves you time,

How do we help the responsible team get
traction? A lot of times as a tech
artist, you find the thing that's
expensive and you're like, "Oh, like
it's right there." But then content
creators, engineers, they don't know

First of all, it's helpful to have a

and discussing and discussing findings.
Um, for example, a Slack channel is

really helpful. Once we get to the point

there's a lot of information that we

all that info is there.
First off, you want to have a really
clear, concise issue summary. You'll
want to include a Jira link once the
Jira has been created. You'll want to do
a basic analysis of what the problem is.
So, as a tech artist, I wouldn't worry

the work that you've done with the
analysis can be passed off to the next

If you're developing on multiple

you'll want to also include which GPU

Next, include the change list for the

um of the build uh of the issue um in
the build.
Then as much media as you can provide
like the better really really helpful.
So screenshots, videos, anything you can
provide to help provide context.
Then provide a screenshot of the trace
with the area of concern highlighted,
similar to what I did earlier in this
presentation. And then finally, the
location of the trace file. If you put

process, um, I highly recommend working
